Authors:
Filipe de Sousa, Yann J.K. Bertrand, Jeff J. Doyle, Bengt
Oxelman, Bernard Pfeil
Title:
Using Genomic Location and Coalescent Simulation to Identify
Paralogy, Hybridisation and Incomplete Lineage Sorting in Nuclear
Phylogenies
Keywords:
phylogenetic incongruence, species tree, gene tree,
coalescent simulation, principal tree, multispecies coalescent
model
Abstract:
Phylogenetic inference is typically based on discrete
genomic DNA sequences, or ‘genes’, but several well-documented processes
can cause discord between gene genealogies and the actual species
phylogeny. Three of the most relevant of these evolutionary processes
are incomplete lineage sorting, hybridisation and paralogy. The
analytical approach required to infer a species tree from gene tree data
differs depending on which of them is suspected to be most likely and
most problematical, but identifying them has been a long standing
challenge. Several existing methods have dealt with these processes but
none has yet been able to untangle all three of them simultaneously.
Here we propose a model by which these three processes can be
successfully identified using genomic location information coupled with
the coalescent model. The potential of the model is evaluated on
simulated data derived from a species network with nine species, of
which one is of hybrid origin, and a single gene duplication that leads
to paralogous comparisons. On a first step, putative paralogous genes
are identified and excluded and, on a second step, blocks of linked
genes are grouped according to their hybrid history. Existing
multispecies coalescent software can then be applied to recover the
species tree without violating the underlying model. As an empirical
case study, the model is also applied to a set 12 genes from seven
species belonging to the plant genus Medicago. We demonstrate that the
information derived from specific genomic locations can be used to
reduce the effect of paralogous genes and to sort genes when
hybridisation is present. We therefore propose a reappraisal of data
acquisition strategies for species tree inference.
